title: Ben Gronow
text:
Benjamin Gronow (10 March 1887 – 24 November 1967) was a Welsh <a href="List%20of%20dual-code%20rugby%20internationals">dual-code international</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, and professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1900s, 1910s and 1920s. At club level Gronow played under the union code for <a href="Bridgend%20Ravens">Bridgend RFC</a>, county rugby for <a href="Glamorgan%20County%20RFC">Glamorgan</a>, and international rugby for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>. He was often used as a utility <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>. When he switched to professional league rugby he represented <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a> (two spells), Grenfell, <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a> and <a href="Featherstone%20Rovers">Featherstone Rovers</a> (<a href="Captain%20%28sports%29">captain</a>) (<a href="List%20of%20Featherstone%20Rovers%20players">Heritage № 82</a>), while at representative level, Gronow played for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> and <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a>. His playing position varied under the league code being used as a <a href="Goal%20%28sports%29%23Rugby%20football">goal</a>-kicking <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a> (prior to the specialist positions of; ), during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s.
Playing career.
While playing <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> at <a href="Bridgend%20Ravens">Bridgend RFC</a>, in 1910 Gronow won four <a href="cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>. Gronow won eight <a href="cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a> under the league code, between 1910 and 1923 while playing for Huddersfield. Gronow was also capped for the <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> rugby league team while at Huddersfield, in 1911 against Australia (2 matches), and after being selected for the <a href="1920%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour">1920 Great Britain Lions tour</a> of Australasia, against Australia (2 matches), and New Zealand (3 matches).
Ben Gronow played as a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>, i.e. number 8, in <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>'s 2–8 defeat by <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> in the <a href="1910%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1910</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1910%E2%80%9311%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season">1910–11 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 3 December 1910, played as a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>, i.e. number 10, and scored 4-<a href="Goal%20%28sport%29%23Rugby%20football">goal</a>s in the 18–8 victory over <a href="Dewsbury">Dewsbury</a> in the <a href="1919%20%28Spring%29%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1919</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1918%E2%80%9319%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season">1918–19 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 17 May 1919, played as a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>, i.e. number 10, and scored 3-<a href="Goal%20%28sport%29%23Rugby%20football">goal</a>s in the 24–5 victory over <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> in the <a href="1919%20%28Autumn%29%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1919</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1919%E2%80%9320%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season">1919–20 season</a> at <a href="Thrum%20Hall">Thrum Hall</a>, <a href="Halifax%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Halifax</a> on Saturday 29 November 1919, and played as a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>, i.e. number 8, and scored a <a href="Goal%20%28sport%29%23Rugby%20football">goal</a> in the 4–10 defeat by <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="1923%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1923</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1923%E2%80%9324%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1923–24 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 24 November 1923.
Gronow also played at least one game for the <a href="Other%20Nationalities%20rugby%20league%20team">Other Nationalities</a> team, on 5 February 1921 against England. The game was notable for the Other Nationalities side being entirely composed of Welsh players; but despite approaches to have the game recognised as a 'Wales' v England encounter the rugby league authorities refused to accept the request. Gronow became one of less than twenty-five Welshmen to have scored more than 1000-points in their rugby league career.
Gronow was selected for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Huddersfield for the <a href="1924%20Great%20Britain%20Lions%20tour%20of%20Australia%20and%20New%20Zealand">1924 Great Britain Lions tour of Australia and New Zealand</a>, he did not play in any of the <a href="Test%20match%20%28rugby%20league%29">Test match</a>es on this tour.
In 1925 Gronow became the first British player to move down under when he went from Huddersfield to <a href="Grenfell%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Grenfell, New South Wales</a> as their coach but returned two years later.
Ben Gronow made his début for Featherstone Rovers on Wednesday 13 March 1929.
Ben Gronow appears to have scored no drop-goals (or field-goals as they are currently known in Australasia), but prior to the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1974–75 season</a> all goals, whether; <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">conversion</a>s, <a href="Penalty%20%28rugby%29%23Penalties%20in%20rugby%20league">penalties</a>, or <a href="Drop%20goal%23Rugby%20league">drop-goal</a>s, scored 2-points, consequently prior to this date drop-goals were often not explicitly documented, therefore '0' drop-goals may indicate drop-goals not recorded, rather than no drop-goals scored. In addition, prior to the <a href="1949%E2%80%9350%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1949–50 season</a>, the archaic <a href="Field%20goal%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">field-goal</a> was also still a valid means of scoring points.
Coaching career.
Gronow was the coach for rugby union team <a href="Morley%20R.F.C.">Morley R.F.C.</a> in the 1930s, however when a history of the club was produced some years later, due to his previous rugby league associations, he was identified as 'unknown' in a team photograph.
